quoteFirst: On the evening of April 14, 1865, while seated in a box at Ford's Theatre, witnessing the play, "Our American Cousin," he was shot by an actor, J. Wilkes Booth, and at
quoteLast: on the morning of the 15th his life ended. His body was embalmed and taken, in funeral procession, from Washington through Baltimore, Harrisburg, Philadelphia, New York, Albany, Buffalo, Cleveland, and Chicago to Springfield, and was buried on May 4th at Oak Ridge Cemetery.
title:
Great Men and Famous Women. Vol. 4
A series of pen and pencil sketches of the lives of more than 200 of the most prominent personages in History
author: Horne, Charles F. (Charles Francis), 1870-1942 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Sunrise occurs at 4:58, 4:42, and 4:32 a. m., on the 1st, 16th, and 30th, respectively, while sunset is at 6:55, 7:10, and
quoteLast: on the corresponding days. Day breaks on the 16th at 2:43 a. m., and twilight ends at 9:09 p. m., giving eighteen hours and twenty-seven minutes from “early dawn to dewy eve.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, May 1885, No. 8
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: The bleeding President was carried to a house across the street, No. 516, where he died at
quoteLast: the next morning. The body was taken to the White House and, after lying in state in the East Room and at the Capitol, left Washington on the 21st of April, stopping at various places en route, and finally arriving at Springfield on the 3rd of May.
title: Lincoln's Birthday
author: Schauffler, Robert Haven, 1879-1964 [Editor]

quoteFirst: At 7.5 P.M. according to a report from the _Shannon_, of the 2nd Cruiser Squadron, the _Shannon’s_ course was S. 10 W., “the 2nd Cruiser Squadron endeavouring to take station on the engaged bow of the Battle Fleet; the Battle Fleet still engaged, the battle cruisers not engaged and turned slightly to port.” And again at
quoteLast: a report says: “The _Duke of Edinburgh_ had now taken station astern of the _Shannon_, the battle cruisers were engaged and had wheeled to starboard. Leading ships of the 2nd Cruiser Squadron were starting to cross the bows of the Battle Fleet from port to starboard.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: As the dawn came and the lamplight grew pale, his pulse began to fail; but his face, even then, was scarcely more haggard than those of the sorrowing men around him. His automatic moaning ceased, a look of unspeakable peace came upon his worn features, and at
quoteLast: he died. Stanton broke the silence by saying:
title:
A Short Life of Abraham Lincoln
Condensed from Nicolay & Hay's Abraham Lincoln: A History
author: Nicolay, John G. (John George), 1832-1901

quoteFirst: Robert Lincoln soon reached the scene, and the members of the cabinet and personal friends crowded around the place of the fearful tragedy. And there the strong constitution of Mr. Lincoln struggled with death, until
quoteLast: the next morning, when his heart ceased to beat. The scene during that long fearful night of woe, at the house of Peterson, beggars description.
title: Sketch of the life of Abraham Lincoln
author: Arnold, Isaac N., 1815-1884

quoteFirst: Dennison, and the others arranged along at his left, and the surgeons were sitting upon the side and foot of the bed, holding the President’s hands, and with their watches observing the slow declension of the pulse, and watching the faint ebb of that noble spirit. Such was the solemn stillness for the duration of five minutes that the ticking of many watches could be heard in the room. At
quoteLast: , A. M., the soul of Abraham Lincoln fled from its earthly tabernacle “to that bourne from which no traveler returns.” As he drew his last breath the Rev. Dr. Gurley addressed the Throne of Grace with a fervent prayer for his heart-broken family and his mourning country.
title: Pictorial history of the war for the Union, volume 2 (of 2)
author: Stephens, Ann S. (Ann Sophia), 1810-1886

title: Pictorial history of the war for the Union, volume 2 (of 2)
author: Stephens, Ann S. (Ann Sophia), 1810-1886

quoteFirst: Too well had the assassin done his work! The President never spoke, or recovered consciousness. He was carried from the theatre to a house near at hand, where, at
quoteLast: the next morning, he expired, with his mourning friends around him.
title: The Backwoods Boy; or, The Boyhood and Manhood of Abraham Lincoln
author: Alger, Horatio, Jr., 1832-1899

quoteFirst: About dawn his pulse began to fail. A little later, "a look of unspeakable peace came over his worn features"(15), and at
quoteLast: on the morning of the fifteenth of April, he died.
title: Lincoln; An Account of his Personal Life, Especially of its Springs of Action as Revealed and Deepened by the Ordeal of War
author: Stephenson, Nathaniel W. (Nathaniel Wright), 1867-1935

quoteFirst: The automatic moaning ceased. A look of unspeakable peace came to the face the world now knows so well. In a solemn hush, at
quoteLast: in the morning of Saturday, April 15, 1865, the great soul of Abraham Lincoln went back to the God Who had given him to America and to the world. A moment later Stanton spoke:
title:
Tom Strong, Lincoln's Scout
A Story of the United States in the Times That Tried Men's Souls
author: Mason, Alfred Bishop, 1851-1933

quoteFirst: But for his powerful physique and his abundant vitality, it would have brought instant death. He never recovered consciousness, but lingered through the night and died at
quoteLast: in the morning. Dr. Gurley, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, which the President attended, was kneeling in prayer by his bedside; Surgeon-General Barnes, of the army, had his finger upon the President's pulse; Robert Lincoln, Senator Sumner, and one of the assistant secretaries leaned upon the foot of the bed.
title: Abraham Lincoln
author: Curtis, William Eleroy, 1850-1911

quoteFirst: At about seven in the morning his breathing became more difficult, and was interrupted at intervals sometimes for so long a time that he was supposed to be dead. At
quoteLast: he ceased breathing, and thus expired.
title:
Complete Life of William McKinley and Story of His Assassination
An Authentic and Official Memorial Edition, Containing Every Incident in the Career of the Immortal Statesman, Soldier, Orator and Patriot
author: Everett, Marshall, 1863-1939

quoteFirst: In the course of the day fifty-five mail bags are forwarded, containing about 20,000 letters; the trains used being those leaving at 3.10 a.m., 7.50 a.m., 9.35 a.m., 11.40 a.m., 12.13 p.m., 1.54 p.m., 3.0 p.m., 3.43 p.m., 4.45 p.m.,
quoteLast: , and 12.45 a.m. So numerous are the London and "London forward" letters in the evening, that three clerks are engaged from 5.0 p.m. to midnight in sorting them. In the opposite direction fifty mail bags are received from London daily, containing about 30,000 letters.
title: The Bristol Royal Mail: Post, Telegraph, and Telephone
author: Tombs, Robert Charles, 1842-1923
